comment_text: A few comments let us know the links to the sources were broken. Thank you! We've fixed those links.

For anyone believing such reaearch is useless or silly, I imagine this research could potentially be helpful in figuring out issues with urination in humans. For instance, figuring out a man's flow rate per unit volume might help with prostate issue diagnosis. I wish there was also a way to use this to help those with incontinence issues, particularly women (including a family member of mine), whose apparatus often gets deranged following pregnancies. If we could figure out a safe way to put a kink in their hoses, perhaps with a wearable pressure device, that could save them hundreds of dollars in incontinence products, as well as the embarrassment of lingering odor. Can we invent a women's pad with a lump in it that wouldn't be uncomfortable, and yet would allow them to control things in a more normal fashion? Or perhaps surgically introduce a gel pack, similar to artificial breast material, with just enough pressure to prevent unintended releases? Would that be like a lump, or would it need to be circular, with the urethra snipped and sewn back together after threading through it? For that matter, that might help some men as well. Perhaps a tiny, surgically implanted clamp, that would only open at a specific pressure, then would close when not having said pressure applied, but not close so tightly so as to affect blood supply? Perhaps one with an external, electronic control, so they could operate it intentionally, but which wouldn't be able to stay closed if they waited too long? Because obviously, someone could damage their kidneys if they tried to hold it in too long, or forgot to use it, due to dementia.

I'm stuck on aquatic mammals peeing at depth. I get that pressure increases with depth in water, but animals are too squishy to offer resistance to the ambient pressure. So in a non-peeing whale, shouldn't the pressure in its bladder be  nearly equal to the external pressure?  I'd also assume pee, like water, is almost incompressible so I wouldn't expect a major viscosity change. Cold water shrinkage may be a factor though, IDK.

So an actually cogent question here:
Why then does it take, say, a diabetic much longer?
I ask this because my husband is diabetic and has been for quite a long time, and I haven't heard an explanation yet for why it can take him up to a minute or more (yes we timed him) to void his bladder in the morning. Now, the closest guess I've heard from a doctor is that diabetics often have enlarged bladders - and that does seem to be the case for hubby, as he can hold a bit over one liter (again, things you learn, that one because hospital stays where they wanted us to collect the fluid for 24 hours...)

Anyway, what's the deal there? It seems like hydrostatic pressure would be greater if there's more fluid present, right? It seems like there'd be enough pressure from that to make up for there being more fluid, even if the pipe width hasn't changed...?
